db:abstract.db:para: Demonstrates how to print web pages using Qt WebEngine Widgets.

db:article.db:para: PrintMe demonstrates how to use the QWebEnginePage and QPrintDialog classes to print a web page. Further, it shows how to implement print preview by using the QPrintPreviewDialog class. For completeness, it also illustrates how to trigger a printing request within JavaScript.

db:section.db:title: Running the Example
db:section.db:para: To run the example from Qt Creator, open the Welcome mode and select the example from Examples. For more information, visit Building and Running an Example.

db:section.db:title: Simple HTML Page
db:section.db:para: In this example, we create an internal HTML page that is added as a resource collection file (.qrc). The page shows only a small HTML message box that explains how to trigger printing by using keyboard shortcuts or clicking a button. The button has the JavaScript onclick event attribute that calls the JavaScript window.print() function.

db:section.db:title: Main Function
db:section.db:para: In the main function, we first instantiate a QWebEngineView and set the URL to our internal HTML page. Next, we create a PrintHandler instance and pass the requested page. For convenience, we also create keyboard shortcuts that can be used to call a print dialog or print preview dialog.

db:section.db:title: Print Handler
db:section.db:para: In the PrintHandler class, we first implement printPreview(), where we instantiate QPrintPreviewDialog. We need the QPrintPreviewDialog::paintRequested handle to generate a set of preview pages.

Now we can implement the PrintHandler::printDocument() slot, which is called in response to the QPrintPreviewDialog::paintRequested signal. To do actual painting on a printer, we call the QWebEngineView::print() function. Printing is an async operation in Chromium, but not in Qt, so we run a local event loop using QEventLoop::exec() to make sure printing is done before returning. User input is blocked, since clicking on a button while we're waiting for the print to finish can mess up the internal state and cause a crash.

To get notified about the result of printing job, we implement PrintHandler::printFinished() slot as handler of QWebEngineView::printFinished() signal. We check for success and report any errors that occurred. Finally, we call QEventLoop::quit() to exit out of the local event loop.
The last function we implement, PrintHandler::print(), is trivial, because it simply opens QPrintDialog and calls the previously implemented PrintHandler::printDocument().
